probably taken pictures with cameras that can track people's faces and then focus correctly on them or track your
pets and then focus correctly on them so this is technology that's been around for decades now I believe there was
actually research in the 1950s and 1960s on being able to identify a face in a
photograph or to be able to identify the landscape versus the sky versus trees versus grass and all of these kinds of
fundamental classification problems or image tracking or detection problems
this was an area called computer vision which has been around for over 40 or 50 years so what has happened between 40 or
50 years ago and now well back then you were writing these algorithms by hand you would write them presumably on punch
cards and put them into the mainframe computers like the ones shown there and then the mainframe computer would crunch
out some data and you'd be able to write these programs they would run I'll be it fairly slowly and you would have
these you know kind of ways to to identify photographs so now we zoom to
the present and we have AI and something called deep learning which is a big area of AI where you're actually training
algorithms that are mimicking the human brain in the way the human brain operates and you're training the
algorithms to recognize something or recognize faces or recognize characters and we also can run them in real time we
can also run them because of AI and because of this deep learning technology you can actually achieve very very high
accuracy so now an algorithm can achieve 99 or 100 almost close to 100% accuracy
with a very sophisticated AI algorithm where in the past maybe you'll get 70% accuracy maybe that was good enough or
on your camera 15 years ago tracking faces maybe it didn't pick up
everybody's face but it picked up most people's faces so that was good enough but with deep learning now with the larger your dataset the
larger of the amount of data that you have to train your algorithm the more accurate your algorithm can become and
also the more sophisticated the algorithm is in other words the more computations required by the algorithm
again the more accurate it can become and it's also now miniaturized so you'll

chip chips this small can now do much better than what those large computers could do in the 1960s but it is still
amazing that hundreds of millions of transistors on these chips can still do computer vision so this can do roughly
four trillion operations per second of 16-bit floating-point calculations per
second and that can be used to do AI in a miniature product like a small camera or wearable or something like that so
let's move on to talk about what is the edge this is now become a very hot topic

imaging but in this area you'll see their their devices that are at the edge

gateways it comes with various names but this edge compute node is also
considered the edge because it's where these cameras are being terminated and it may also have some intelligence so

local on-premise appliances so that's what we call the edge the edge devices and the edge servers or the edge compute
node and then on the other hand if I go to the other side of this continuum you
have the network hub that these are connected to when they're connected to the cloud and then you have the cloud or
the data center in the back so you have this continuum of the cloud which is where you have a lot of performance

at the edge and that's why it's so exciting is to be able to put the performance required for AI all the way

bit resolution and as you require fewer bits you can do more computations but then it's also not as quite not quite as
accurate so you lose some accuracy but you have to do very special techniques to try to counterbalance that so that's
one technique also taking these neural networks where some of the neurons and some of the data coming through might be

advantage of the fact that some of these multiplications you're doing are sparse and so you can do various techniques to
take advantage and get even more computation capability or you have efficient memory so that's something
that we've been working on a lot at Intel is how to get data in and out of the chips and how to get the data flow
to require less power and be much more efficient many of you may not know this but the processing of the data versus
the movement of the data in many cases the movement takes up much more power than the processing itself so don't be
fooled by companies that say well our processor is capable of this much at this power well but what about moving
the data in and out of the chip if it's inefficient then that could cause a lot of power so that's another area also
companies are coming up you'll read articles about new startups that are coming up with accelerators and different kinds of engines for neural

capability that can do it very very efficiently but it's not programmable so then there's a trade-off between program
